confusion_pairs.title: Awareness vs Training

a.definition: Broad messaging to keep security top-of-mind and influence behavior (posters, reminders, comms).

b.definition: Skill-building instruction for doing tasks correctly (hands-on, role-specific, measurable outcomes).

bullets: Awareness = habits and attention; training = competence and performance.
Awareness is broad and frequent; training is deeper and role-focused.
Phishing simulations support awareness; secure admin training supports operations.

confusion_pairs.title: Policy vs Standard vs Procedure vs Guideline

a.definition: High-level, mandatory statements of intent and requirements ('what' and 'why').

b.definition: Standards define specific mandatory controls; procedures define step-by-step 'how'; guidelines are recommended (optional).

bullets: Policy sets direction; standards and procedures implement it.
Procedures are detailed steps; guidelines are flexible suggestions.
Auditors look for policy + enforceable standards + workable procedures.

confusion_pairs.title: Due care vs Due diligence

a.definition: Doing the homework: identify risks, evaluate options, plan controls (before decisions).

b.definition: Doing the work: implement and operate reasonable controls consistently (ongoing duty).

bullets: Diligence = assess/plan; care = implement/operate.
Diligence is often before purchase/launch; care is continuous after.
Skipping diligence leads to bad control choices; skipping care leads to paper-only security.

confusion_pairs.title: MSA vs SOW vs SLA

a.definition: The umbrella contract: legal terms, responsibilities, and relationship rules.

b.definition: SOW defines the work to be done; SLA defines measurable service performance and remedies.

bullets: MSA = the rules; SOW = the work; SLA = the performance targets.
SOW often changes per project; MSA usually stays stable across projects.
SLA without monitoring is just vibes; enforce it with metrics and reporting.

confusion_pairs.title: MOU vs MOA

a.definition: A non-binding or lightly binding understanding of cooperation and intent.

b.definition: A more formal agreement defining responsibilities; often treated as binding in practice.

bullets: MOU = intent to cooperate; MOA = agreed responsibilities and expectations.
Use MOU for exploratory collaboration; MOA when you must define who does what.
Don’t assume either replaces a security addendum or SLA when services are delivered.

confusion_pairs.title: NIST CSF vs NIST RMF

a.definition: A cybersecurity program framework for organizing activities (Identify/Protect/Detect/Respond/Recover).

b.definition: A risk management lifecycle for systems (categorize → select → implement → assess → authorize → monitor).

bullets: CSF = program organization; RMF = system-by-system lifecycle.
CSF is flexible and communication-friendly; RMF is process-heavy and authorization-oriented.
CSF helps you talk to leadership; RMF helps you justify controls and formal risk decisions.

confusion_pairs.title: ISO 27001 vs ISO 27002

a.definition: Requirements for an Information Security Management System (ISMS); certifiable.

b.definition: Guidance and control recommendations to support an ISMS; not the certification standard.

bullets: 27001 = requirements + certification; 27002 = control guidance.
Implement controls (27002) to satisfy the ISMS requirements (27001).
Audits focus on 27001 compliance; 27002 helps you choose and explain controls.

confusion_pairs.title: Centralized vs Decentralized governance

a.definition: Security decisions and standards are controlled by a central authority/team.

b.definition: Security decision-making is distributed across business units (with varying degrees of central oversight).

bullets: Centralized = consistency; decentralized = agility and business alignment.
Decentralization increases drift; centralization can create bottlenecks.
Most orgs use a hybrid: central policies + local implementation.

confusion_pairs.title: Least privilege vs Separation of duties

a.definition: Give users/processes only the access needed to do the job—nothing more.

b.definition: Split critical tasks across multiple people/roles so one person can’t complete abuse end-to-end.

bullets: Least privilege limits access; SoD limits power concentration.
SoD is about workflow design; least privilege is about permissions design.
Two-person control is SoD in action for high-risk operations.

confusion_pairs.title: Job rotation vs Mandatory vacation

a.definition: Periodic role changes to reduce fraud risk and spread knowledge.

b.definition: Forced time away so ongoing fraud (that requires daily actions) is more likely to be discovered.

bullets: Rotation reduces single-person dependency; vacations break continuous control of a scheme.
Both are anti-fraud/insider-risk controls; neither replaces monitoring.
Mandatory vacations are especially useful in finance/privileged admin roles.

confusion_pairs.title: EOL vs EOSL

a.definition: Product is no longer sold/actively developed; support may be winding down.

b.definition: Support and security updates end; running it becomes a growing risk.

bullets: EOL often comes before EOSL; EOSL is the security cliff.
Post‑EOSL = no patches, no vendor help—plan migration.
Treat EOSL exceptions as high-risk with strict compensating controls and time limits.

access.account_lifecycle.deprovisioning.rule: Deprovisioning must be fast and complete: disable accounts, revoke tokens, remove access, rotate shared secrets.
access.account_lifecycle.deprovisioning.micro_example: Terminate SSO session, revoke OAuth tokens, remove from groups, disable VPN.

awareness.anomalous_behavior.rule: Anomalous behavior is 'unusual for this user/device'—investigate before you accuse.
awareness.anomalous_behavior.micro_example: A user suddenly downloads 10GB at 2 AM—trigger an alert and verify.

awareness.insider_threat.rule: Insider threats need controls + culture: monitoring, least privilege, and reporting.
awareness.insider_threat.micro_example: Detect unusual downloads; enforce SoD; encourage anonymous reporting.

awareness.metrics.trends.rule: Use trends to prove improvement (or highlight problems) over time.
awareness.metrics.trends.micro_example: Quarterly trend: click rate down, reporting rate up—keep iterating.

awareness.phishing.campaigns.rule: Phishing campaigns exploit social engineering; awareness reduces success rates.
awareness.phishing.campaigns.micro_example: Teach users to verify senders and avoid urgent payment requests.

awareness.phishing.simulations.rule: Phishing simulations test behavior and improve reporting habits.
awareness.phishing.simulations.micro_example: Run a simulated phish; track clicks and 'report phish' submissions.

awareness.programs.definition.rule: A security awareness program changes behavior through consistent messaging plus measurement.
awareness.programs.definition.micro_example: Monthly micro-lessons + phishing sims + metrics on click rates and reporting.

awareness.reporting_monitoring.rule: Measure awareness outcomes: reporting rates and time-to-report beat vanity completion stats.
awareness.reporting_monitoring.micro_example: Track how quickly users report suspicious email after simulation.

awareness.role_based_training.rule: Role-based training targets job-specific risks and responsibilities.
awareness.role_based_training.micro_example: Finance learns BEC fraud patterns; IT learns incident escalation and change control.

awareness.training.design.rule: Good training is role-based, measurable, and practiced—not a one-time slideshow.
awareness.training.design.micro_example: Developers train on secure coding; HR trains on data handling; measure post-test results.

awareness.training.vs_awareness.rule: Awareness keeps people alert; training teaches people to do tasks correctly.
awareness.training.vs_awareness.micro_example: Awareness: remind about phishing. Training: teach admins secure change procedures.

awareness.user_training.password_managem.rule: Know and apply: awareness user_training password_management.
awareness.user_training.password_managem.micro_example: Translate it into a control, a process, or evidence.

awareness.user_training.removable_media.rule: Know and apply: awareness user_training removable_media.
awareness.user_training.removable_media.micro_example: Translate it into a control, a process, or evidence.

change_mgmt.approval_controls.rule: Approvals separate requesters from implementers and reduce risky changes.
change_mgmt.approval_controls.micro_example: CAB approval required for production firewall rule changes.

change_mgmt.backout_plan.rule: Every meaningful change needs a rollback/backout plan.
change_mgmt.backout_plan.micro_example: If deployment fails health checks, automatically roll back to last version.

change_mgmt.documentation.rule: Change documentation creates repeatability and accountability.
change_mgmt.documentation.micro_example: Ticket includes purpose, steps, test plan, rollback, owner, and timestamps.

change_mgmt.documentation.update.rule: Update diagrams/policies/docs after changes—or your documentation becomes a liability.
change_mgmt.documentation.update.micro_example: After VLAN redesign, update network diagram and security policy references.

change_mgmt.documentation.update_diagram.rule: Update diagrams/policies/docs after changes—or your documentation becomes a liability.
change_mgmt.documentation.update_diagram.micro_example: After VLAN redesign, update network diagram and security policy references.

change_mgmt.documentation.update_policie.rule: Update diagrams/policies/docs after changes—or your documentation becomes a liability.
change_mgmt.documentation.update_policie.micro_example: After VLAN redesign, update network diagram and security policy references.

change_mgmt.emergency_changes.rule: Emergency changes happen fast—but still require documentation and post-approval review.
change_mgmt.emergency_changes.micro_example: Hotfix a critical vuln, then do retroactive CAB review within 24–48h.

change_mgmt.goal.availability.rule: Change control protects availability by avoiding untested surprises.
change_mgmt.goal.availability.micro_example: Reject changes without test evidence or rollback plan.

change_mgmt.impact_analysis.dependencies.rule: Impact analysis maps dependencies so changes don’t break downstream systems.
change_mgmt.impact_analysis.dependencies.micro_example: App update requires DB schema change and service restart—schedule together.

change_mgmt.maintenance_windows.rule: Maintenance windows reduce business impact by scheduling downtime.
change_mgmt.maintenance_windows.micro_example: Apply network firmware updates Sunday 2–4 AM local time.

change_mgmt.overview.rule: Change management reduces outages and security drift by controlling how changes happen.
change_mgmt.overview.micro_example: Require approvals, testing, and a rollback plan before production changes.

change_mgmt.schedule_implement.micro_example: Pre-stage configs, validate in staging, deploy in window, verify, then close ticket.

change_mgmt.security_vs_usability_tradeo.rule: Security controls that break workflows get bypassed—design for usable security.
change_mgmt.security_vs_usability_tradeo.micro_example: MFA with sensible prompts beats overly strict rules that push users to workarounds.

change_mgmt.sop.steps.rule: SOPs define the consistent steps for safe changes.
change_mgmt.sop.steps.micro_example: Standard patch SOP: approve → test → deploy → verify → document.

change_mgmt.technical_implications.allow.rule: Know the allow/deny implications: a default-allow rule-set is a breach waiting to happen.
change_mgmt.technical_implications.allow.micro_example: Use default-deny with explicit allows for inbound services.

change_mgmt.technical_implications.depen.rule: Dependencies determine blast radius—map them before changes.
change_mgmt.technical_implications.depen.micro_example: Updating a shared library can break multiple services; test consumers.

change_mgmt.technical_implications.servi.rule: Service restarts can be outages—coordinate and communicate.
change_mgmt.technical_implications.servi.micro_example: Restart identity service after config change; monitor auth failures.

change_mgmt.version_control.rule: Version control provides traceability for config and code changes.
change_mgmt.version_control.micro_example: Track firewall configs in git; tie commits to approved change tickets.

compliance.consequences.fines_sanctions.rule: Noncompliance has consequences—money, reputation, or both.
compliance.consequences.fines_sanctions.micro_example: PCI violation can trigger fines; GDPR issues can trigger sanctions and trust loss.

compliance.consequences.reputation.rule: Noncompliance has consequences—money, reputation, or both.
compliance.consequences.reputation.micro_example: PCI violation can trigger fines; GDPR issues can trigger sanctions and trust loss.

compliance.gdpr.rule: GDPR governs personal data processing; focus on lawful basis, rights, and protection of PII.
compliance.gdpr.micro_example: Minimize data, restrict access, and ensure breach notification processes exist.

compliance.monitoring.acknowledgment.micro_example: Employees sign acceptable use policy on hire and annually.

compliance.monitoring.attestation.rule: Attestation is a formal statement that controls/processes meet requirements.
compliance.monitoring.attestation.micro_example: Manager attests quarterly that access reviews were completed.

compliance.monitoring.due_care.rule: Due care: operate reasonable controls consistently over time.
compliance.monitoring.due_care.micro_example: Ongoing patching, logging reviews, and access recertification.

compliance.monitoring.due_diligence.rule: Due diligence: assess risks and select controls before committing.
compliance.monitoring.due_diligence.micro_example: Vendor assessment before signing: questionnaires, audit reports, pen test scope.

compliance.pci_dss.rule: PCI DSS applies to cardholder data environments—segment and harden systems that touch CHD.
compliance.pci_dss.micro_example: Isolate payment processing network and enforce strict logging and access control.

compliance.reporting.external.rule: Compliance reporting must match audience: internal assurance vs external regulators/auditors.
compliance.reporting.external.micro_example: Internal: control status dashboards. External: formal audit artifacts and attestations.

compliance.reporting.internal.rule: Compliance reporting must match audience: internal assurance vs external regulators/auditors.
compliance.reporting.internal.micro_example: Internal: control status dashboards. External: formal audit artifacts and attestations.

compliance.requirements.rule: Compliance requirements are external constraints—translate them into enforceable controls.
compliance.requirements.micro_example: Map PCI DSS to network segmentation, logging, and access controls.

frameworks.benchmarks.cis.rule: CIS Benchmarks provide practical hardening baselines for systems and apps.
frameworks.benchmarks.cis.micro_example: Use CIS Windows benchmark to set audit policy and disable insecure services.

frameworks.iso.27001.rule: ISO 27001 defines ISMS requirements and is certifiable.
frameworks.iso.27001.micro_example: Implement an ISMS, run internal audits, and pursue certification.

frameworks.iso.27002.rule: ISO 27002 gives guidance on security controls supporting an ISMS.
frameworks.iso.27002.micro_example: Use 27002 control guidance to design your access control policy and standards.

frameworks.iso.27701.rule: ISO 27701 extends privacy management (PIMS) on top of an ISMS.
frameworks.iso.27701.micro_example: Add privacy controls and roles to support personal data obligations.

frameworks.iso.31000.rule: ISO 31000 is broad risk management guidance—not security-only.
frameworks.iso.31000.micro_example: Use it to structure enterprise risk discussions beyond cyber.

frameworks.nist.csf.communication.rule: CSF is a communication tool: translate security work into business outcomes.
frameworks.nist.csf.communication.micro_example: Map projects to CSF functions for leadership reporting.

frameworks.nist.csf.core_functions.rule: NIST CSF core functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover.
frameworks.nist.csf.core_functions.micro_example: Detect = monitoring; Respond = containment; Recover = restore services.

frameworks.nist.csf.functions.rule: NIST CSF core functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover.
frameworks.nist.csf.functions.micro_example: Detect = monitoring; Respond = containment; Recover = restore services.

frameworks.nist.csf.purpose.rule: CSF organizes security outcomes—use it to build and explain a security program.
frameworks.nist.csf.purpose.micro_example: Use CSF to gap-assess and prioritize roadmap items.

frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier1.rule: CSF Tier 1: Partial—ad hoc risk practices, inconsistent.
frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier1.micro_example: Controls exist but vary by team; little formal risk process.

frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier2.rule: CSF Tier 2: Risk-informed—approved practices exist but not organization-wide.
frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier2.micro_example: Some policies exist; implementation depends on business unit.

frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier3.rule: CSF Tier 3: Repeatable—formal, consistent risk management practices.
frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier3.micro_example: Standard processes for asset mgmt, access, and monitoring across teams.

frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier4.rule: CSF Tier 4: Adaptive—continuous improvement using lessons learned and intelligence.
frameworks.nist.csf.tiers.tier4.micro_example: Metrics + threat intel drive rapid control updates and automation.

frameworks.nist.csf.vs_rmf.rule: CSF organizes program outcomes; RMF is the lifecycle for system risk decisions.
frameworks.nist.csf.vs_rmf.micro_example: Use CSF for program maturity, RMF for system authorization.

frameworks.nist.rmf.definition.rule: NIST RMF is a system lifecycle for selecting, assessing, authorizing, and monitoring controls.
frameworks.nist.rmf.definition.micro_example: Categorize system → pick controls → assess → authorize → continuous monitoring.

frameworks.secure_config_guides.rule: Secure configuration guides turn 'best practice' into repeatable baselines.
frameworks.secure_config_guides.micro_example: Apply a hardened OS baseline, then monitor drift from it.

governance.corporate.board_authority.rule: The board sets risk appetite and holds executives accountable.
governance.corporate.board_authority.micro_example: Board approves security strategy and receives KPI/KRI reports.

governance.grc.definition.rule: GRC = Governance, Risk, and Compliance: how an org sets direction, manages risk, and proves obligations.
governance.grc.definition.micro_example: Policies + risk register + audit evidence in one coherent program.

governance.infosec.alignment.rule: Security must align to business goals—otherwise it becomes ignored or defunded.
governance.infosec.alignment.micro_example: Prioritize controls that protect revenue-critical systems first.

governance.infosec.enforcement.policies.rule: Policies without enforcement are fiction—define ownership and consequences.
governance.infosec.enforcement.policies.micro_example: Policy violations trigger exception process or disciplinary action.

governance.infosec.extension.rule: Security extends beyond IT: business processes and vendors are part of the threat surface.
governance.infosec.extension.micro_example: TPRM controls apply to SaaS providers handling sensitive data.

governance.models.centralized.rule: Centralized governance enforces consistent standards and faster control rollouts.
governance.models.centralized.micro_example: One security team defines baselines for all business units.

governance.models.decentralized.rule: Decentralized governance improves local fit but risks inconsistent controls.
governance.models.decentralized.micro_example: Each division chooses tools; central team sets minimum policy guardrails.

governance.policies.rule: Governance policies are the top-level rules—everything else inherits from them.
governance.policies.micro_example: A data classification policy drives standards for encryption and retention.

governance.structures.committees.rule: Committees (like CAB or security steering) make cross-team decisions and reduce silos.
governance.structures.committees.micro_example: Security steering committee prioritizes risk reduction projects.

governance.structures.regulators.rule: Regulators define constraints—design controls to meet them proactively.
governance.structures.regulators.micro_example: Financial regulator requires retention and monitoring; build evidence pipelines.

mitigation.least_privilege.micro_example: Translate it into a control, a process, or evidence.

personnel.clean_desk.rule: Clean desk policies reduce shoulder-surfing and accidental exposure.
personnel.clean_desk.micro_example: Lock screens; store documents; no passwords on sticky notes.

personnel.fraud_controls.rule: Fraud controls combine SoD, monitoring, and periodic independent review.
personnel.fraud_controls.micro_example: Reconcile payments and audit privileged admin activity.

personnel.job_rotation.rule: Job rotation reduces fraud risk and prevents single points of failure.
personnel.job_rotation.micro_example: Rotate payroll duties quarterly; anomalies surface when a new person takes over.

personnel.least_privilege.rule: Least privilege: grant only what’s needed, review regularly, and remove quickly.
personnel.least_privilege.micro_example: Developers don’t need prod DB write access; use just-in-time elevation.

personnel.mandatory_vacations.rule: Mandatory vacations help uncover fraud that requires constant attention.
personnel.mandatory_vacations.micro_example: Force 2-week vacation for traders/admins; monitoring catches irregularities.

personnel.nda.rule: NDAs define confidentiality expectations and legal consequences.
personnel.nda.micro_example: Vendor signs NDA before seeing architecture diagrams or customer data.

personnel.offboarding.rule: Offboarding must remove access fast—accounts, tokens, devices, and shared secrets.
personnel.offboarding.micro_example: Disable SSO, revoke MFA tokens, and collect badges on last day.

personnel.offboarding.exit_interview.rule: Exit interviews can surface risks (data exfil, grievances) but don’t replace technical controls.
personnel.offboarding.exit_interview.micro_example: Ask about outstanding access; verify by disabling accounts and checking logs.

personnel.privilege_creep.rule: Privilege creep happens when access accumulates—fix with periodic access reviews and deprovisioning.
personnel.privilege_creep.micro_example: Quarterly recertification removes stale group memberships.

personnel.separation_of_duties.rule: Separate duties so no single person can complete abuse end-to-end.
personnel.separation_of_duties.micro_example: One person requests payment; another approves; a third reconciles.

personnel.social_media_policy.rule: Social media policies reduce oversharing that helps attackers (OSINT).
personnel.social_media_policy.micro_example: No posting badge photos, internal screenshots, or travel patterns.

personnel.two_person_control.rule: Two-person control requires a second person for high-risk actions.
personnel.two_person_control.micro_example: Two admins must approve key escrow access or HSM key ceremonies.

physical.security.policies.rule: Physical security policies protect facilities and hardware—cyber controls don’t matter if attackers can walk in.
physical.security.policies.micro_example: Badge access, visitor logs, and locked server rooms.

policy.documents.guideline.rule: Guidelines are recommended best practices—flexible, not mandatory.
policy.documents.guideline.micro_example: Guideline suggests using password managers; not an enforcement doc.

policy.documents.policy.rule: Policies are mandatory high-level rules approved by leadership.
policy.documents.policy.micro_example: AUP policy states acceptable systems use and consequences.

policy.documents.policy.approval_level.rule: Approval level defines who can authorize the document and changes.
policy.documents.policy.approval_level.micro_example: Security policy approved by CISO; standards approved by security leadership.

policy.documents.procedure.rule: Procedures are step-by-step instructions to implement standards.
policy.documents.procedure.micro_example: Procedure: how to onboard a new user and assign groups.

policy.documents.standard.rule: Standards are mandatory specifics that make policy enforceable.
policy.documents.standard.micro_example: Password standard: min length, MFA, lockout, rotation rules.

policy.encryption_standard.rule: Encryption standards define approved algorithms, key sizes, and where encryption is mandatory.
policy.encryption_standard.micro_example: Require TLS 1.2+ and AES; forbid RC4 and weak hashes.

policy.examples.aup.rule: AUP defines acceptable use, prohibited activities, and monitoring expectations.
policy.examples.aup.micro_example: No pirated software; no bypassing controls; consent to monitoring.

policy.exceptions.compensating_controls.rule: Compensating controls reduce risk when you can’t meet the standard.
policy.exceptions.compensating_controls.micro_example: Can’t patch fast? Add network isolation + monitoring + strict access.

policy.exceptions.exception_process.rule: Use a formal exception process: request → risk assessment → approval → review/expiry.
policy.exceptions.exception_process.micro_example: Ticketed exception with owner, scope, and expiry date.

policy.exceptions.legacy_exception.rule: Legacy exceptions are high-risk; require remediation plans and strict deadlines.
policy.exceptions.legacy_exception.micro_example: Unpatchable OS allowed only behind firewall + jump host + monitoring.

policy.exceptions.remediation_plan.rule: Every exception needs a plan to remove it.
policy.exceptions.remediation_plan.micro_example: Upgrade path + date + resources; track milestones.

policy.exceptions.risk_assessment.rule: Risk assessment justifies why the exception is acceptable (or not).
policy.exceptions.risk_assessment.micro_example: Assess likelihood/impact; document residual risk and sign-off.

policy.exceptions.scope_duration.rule: Define scope and duration or your exception becomes a loophole.
policy.exceptions.scope_duration.micro_example: Applies to 3 servers in DMZ for 60 days only.

policy.external_considerations.industry.rule: External considerations (industry/regulatory) shape what policies must require.
policy.external_considerations.industry.micro_example: Healthcare: privacy rules; payments: PCI DSS; EU users: GDPR constraints.

policy.external_considerations.regulator.rule: External considerations (industry/regulatory) shape what policies must require.
policy.external_considerations.regulator.micro_example: Healthcare: privacy rules; payments: PCI DSS; EU users: GDPR constraints.

policy.framework.mandatory_vs_optional.rule: Mandatory controls must be followed; optional guidance is best-effort.
policy.framework.mandatory_vs_optional.micro_example: Standard says 'must encrypt laptops'; guideline says 'should encrypt USB drives.'

policy.framework.overview.rule: Policy frameworks define how policy documents fit together and get enforced.
policy.framework.overview.micro_example: Define document hierarchy, ownership, review cycles, and exception handling.

tprm.agreements.bpa.rule: BPA defines how purchases are handled (pricing/terms) for repeated buying.
tprm.agreements.bpa.micro_example: Pre-negotiated rates for security assessments over a year.

tprm.agreements.moa.rule: MOA defines responsibilities for cooperation; more formal than an MOU.
tprm.agreements.moa.micro_example: Org A provides hosting; Org B provides monitoring; response timelines defined.

tprm.agreements.mou.rule: MOU documents cooperation intent; often non-binding.
tprm.agreements.mou.micro_example: Two orgs agree to share threat intel contacts.

tprm.agreements.msa.rule: MSA is the umbrella agreement: legal terms and responsibilities.
tprm.agreements.msa.micro_example: Defines liability, confidentiality, and dispute terms across projects.

tprm.agreements.nda.rule: NDA protects confidential info during vendor evaluation and delivery.
tprm.agreements.nda.micro_example: Vendor can access design docs only after NDA is signed.

tprm.agreements.sla.rule: SLA defines uptime/response targets and penalties—monitor it.
tprm.agreements.sla.micro_example: 99.9% uptime with service credits if breached; monthly SLA reports.

tprm.agreements.sow_wo.rule: SOW/WO defines deliverables, scope, timelines, and acceptance criteria.
tprm.agreements.sow_wo.micro_example: SOW for SOC service includes log sources, onboarding dates, and acceptance tests.

tprm.vendor_assessment.pen_test.rule: Pen tests validate real-world exposure—define scope and rules of engagement.
tprm.vendor_assessment.pen_test.micro_example: Test the SaaS tenant under agreed ROE; remediate findings.

tprm.vendor_assessment.right_to_audit.rule: Right-to-audit lets you demand evidence and sometimes run assessments.
tprm.vendor_assessment.right_to_audit.micro_example: Contract allows requesting logs and audit reports during incidents.

tprm.vendor_assessment.sensitive_info_ac.rule: Limit vendor access to sensitive data; enforce least privilege and monitoring.
tprm.vendor_assessment.sensitive_info_ac.micro_example: Vendor accounts are time-bound, MFA-protected, and logged.

tprm.vendor_monitoring.rules_of_engageme.rule: Rules of engagement define what testing/monitoring is allowed and how to report issues.
tprm.vendor_monitoring.rules_of_engageme.micro_example: Pen test ROE: targets, time windows, safety rules, and escalation contacts.

tprm.vendor_monitoring.transition_planni.rule: Transition planning prevents lock-in and chaos if a vendor fails or is replaced.
tprm.vendor_monitoring.transition_planni.micro_example: Plan data export, account migration, and cutover steps before contract ends.

tprm.vendor_selection.conflict_of_intere.rule: Conflicts of interest corrupt assessments—separate evaluators from sellers.
tprm.vendor_selection.conflict_of_intere.micro_example: The vendor can’t grade their own security homework.

tprm.vendor_selection.due_diligence.rule: Vendor due diligence: assess security posture before you sign.
tprm.vendor_selection.due_diligence.micro_example: Questionnaire + SOC reports + pen test scope + data flow review.

tprm.winding_down.eol_eosl.rule: Winding down vendors/products requires EOL/EOSL planning and secure offboarding.
tprm.winding_down.eol_eosl.micro_example: Export data, revoke access, terminate integrations, and confirm secure deletion.
